p.s: In the speech Boris Johnson compares the role of COP26 with James Bond and the climate change with a ticking bomb or the doomsday device, which is able to destroy the whole world (ll. 2f).
These are metaphors, which are used to make his point easier for his listeners to understand.
They also may be like aan homage to Great Britain, because James Bond is a britishBritish work and the conference takes place in Great Britain.

He also uses certain metaphors to explain the situation of the climate crisis with for example edored wire (l. 4) which stands for the solution to stop climate change or the detonation (l. 5) which stands for the moment when it's too late to stop the rise up of the temperature of the earth.
Johnson creates a feeling of community by using the pronoun we through the whole speech (ll. 5,8,9).
In the second paragraph Johnson starts with the anaphora I was there [...] (ll. 10f).
It's according to conferences from the past and connect that directly to his listeners by telling they visited them together (l. 10).
Johnson says these conferences weren't more than blah, blah, blah (l. 13).
This is used to make fun about them in oder to show that the COP26 is the deciding conference.
He also says that clearly in line 14.
The third paragraph starts with an ellipse and an anaphora.
TroughThrough the ellipse Johnson wants to reduce the sentence to his point.
Also he numents important words of climate change like coal, cars, cash and trees (l. 16), which underlines the large scale of the topic.
The alliteration supports that.
The metaphor doomsday device is used a second time (l. 17).
He wants to explain that it's important to ahndle right now by saying climate and environment was ignored for about the last 200 years (ll. 18f).
In the fifth paragraph he shows that they have all the conditions to start fighting the climate crisis by using an enumeration and anaphora of the things they need but already have (l. 30).
Also he directly talks to the audience with the sentence we all talk about what we're going to do in 2050 or 2060.
Johnson wants to underline that everybody is affected by climate change.
He even talks about children and that they will suffer and judge them if they don't start the fight against climate change, which is a very personal way to talk to the audience.
Johnson uses repetitions and anaphoras to underline that.
He knows that COP26 will not be the final attack against climate change and he makes that clear through the sentence COP26 will not, and cannot, be the end of the story [...].
In line 45 he repeats that all the necessary conditions are reachable or even reached (l. 45).
